thread.title: Why history isn’t repeating for Red Bull
thread.title_full: Why history isn’t repeating for Red Bull

title: Why history isn’t repeating for Red Bull
text:
Source: FOX SPORTS THIS isn’t the history Red Bull hoped to repeat in 2017. 
The first day of F1 running under new rules expected to see Red Bull return to top form instead saw their new car roll to a stop after just four laps. 
The sense of deja-vu extended to the driver: Daniel Ricciardo was at the wheel in 2014 when engine issues scuttled his maiden test as a Red Bull driver, and it was the Australian at the wheel again when an engine issue forced him to park up on Monday. 
REPORT: Hamilton, Mercedes top Day 1 of Barcelona test 
Happily, it wasn’t a harbinger of more serious reliability problems as in 2014 and 2015. 
The Red Bull did spend much of the day in the garage, but Ricciardo emerged with two hours remaining and reeled off a raft trouble-free laps. 
“That was important for us,” Ricciardo said at day’s end. “We racked up close to 50 laps in that last little block. 
“The last few hours gave us a lot of confidence going into tomorrow and I think we can definitely get the ball rolling from here.” 
Renault’s brand new power unit was the heart of the issues, but Red Bull’s head of race engineering Guillaume Rocquelin said the problems were more time-consuming than terminal and are unlikely to trouble the team again tomorrow. 
“Obviously we lost quite a bit of time today, which was frustrating,” he said. “That was largely a function of the issues we had — a sensor problem this morning and then a problem with the energy store later on. 
“Both are hard to access, so required some time to sort out. It meant we didn’t get real track time until around 4pm, but after that we ran without issue. 
“The fixes we put in place cured the issues and we should be good to go tomorrow again.” Ricciardo ended up completing 46 laps in total across Day 1. Source: Getty Images 
Ricciardo’s late running contained a best time of 1m22.926s to sit him fifth at the end of Day 1, a few tenths off his qualifying time for last year’s Spanish Grand Prix and 1.1 seconds off Lewis Hamilton’s quickest time of the day. 
And they have already started to iron out issues with the chassis. 
“From the first run, I went out there and it’s a new car, so you start to feel a few little differences,” Ricciardo said. “We’ve cleaned them up already in the few runs that we had. It’s just going to come with more running. 
“Sure you still have a look where the other cars are in testing but I don’t really read into it too much. If we’re two seconds quicker than everyone, then sure, I’d be pretty happy doing this interview right now. 
“We’re a bit more than a second off but you don’t know fuel loads or anything. 
“Considering the amount of laps we did today, we can be pretty positive about where we sit.” 
Max Verstappen takes over the Red Bull RB13 for the second and fourth days of the test, with Ricciardo back behind the wheel for the third day. View All Comments The latest sports news, in your inbox daily. Email
